Award.AwardTitle: Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute (SAMSI) is a national institute that merges statistical and mathematical thinking to create high impact theory and methodology for fundamental scientific and societal problems. It does so by catalyzing and nurturing collaborations both among its core disciplines -- statistics, probability, and applied mathematics -- and between those disciplines and the physical, social, and engineering sciences, as well as other quantitative disciplines such as computer science and operations research. SAMSI engages researchers at all career stages, from graduate students to postdoctoral fellows to senior international leaders, who take away from SAMSI expanded modes of thought, new vision and energy, and momentum enabling collaborations initiated there to persist. The spectrum of SAMSI's programs over the period 2012-17 responds to national needs, impetus from the statistics and mathematics community, and scientific opportunities with potential high impact. Programs address massive datasets in contexts such as astrophysics and the environment, data-driven decisions in healthcare, identification of structure in high-dimensional data, and computational modeling in the social sciences, as well as other topics to be identified. A broad range of education and outreach activities, focused especially on undergraduates, faculty in teaching institutions, and under-represented minorities, builds greater public awareness of the importance and achievements of the mathematical sciences.

SAMSI is a national institute that exists to advance science and society by catalyzing and supporting collaborations among statisticians, applied mathematicians, and researchers in the natural and social sciences. Its goal is to tackle the most challenging and far-reaching data-driven problems, as exemplified by its forthcoming programs on such topics as massive datasets in astrophysics and the environment, data-driven decisions in healthcare, identifying structure in high-dimensional data, and computational modeling in the social sciences. SAMSI operates by bringing together researchers at all levels -- students, postdoctoral fellows, and senior leaders -- into teams that both make substantial progress within SAMSI programs and form the basis of future collaborations. It stimulates people at all stages of their careers to think differently about the roles and power of applied mathematics and statistics in concert with one another. A vibrant education and outreach program uses SAMSI research to present the importance and achievements of the mathematical sciences to undergraduates, professors at teaching colleges, and the general public. SAMSI activities are permeated by efforts to increase the participation of under-represented minorities in mathematics, statistics, and the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute (SAMSI) is a national institute operating in Research Triangle Park, North Carolina, organized by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Duke University, and North Carolina State University (collectively referred to as the Triangle universities). The principal activity is the organization of year-long research programs on topics covering statistics, applied mathematics and their applications to numerous disciplinary sciences. These research programs engage faculty, postdocs and graduate students from throughout the United States and internationally. Researchers also join from industry, federal agencies and several of the US national laboratories. Participation can take the form of attendance at a workshop (several hundred participants each year), or longer-term visits of up to the full academic year (typically about 25 visitors per year). In addition, there is substantial participation from the Triangle universities, including an average of six postdocs per year who are recruited by SAMSI and supported by the SAMSI grant. Nearly all of these postdocs have gone on to successful careers in academia or industry.

Much of the research activity takes place in working groups – a typical program has between six and twelve working groups studying specific questions within the overall topic of the program. These working groups meet at regular intervals, typically weekly, and engage participants throughout the world through online conference facilities, primarily Webex. Outcomes of these working groups include research papers published in major journals, software products and the organization of research sessions at major conferences. On numerous occasions, a group of researchers that first met through a SAMSI working group has gone on to obtain their own funding from NSF or other grant agencies, thus ensuring the continuation of the research activity beyond the original SAMSI working group.

In addition to its regular programs, SAMSI also organizes summer workshops and programs, occasional free-standing workshops not connected with any year-long program, and outreach and educational activities. The latter includes three workshops per year aimed at undergraduates, and an annual summer program aimed at graduate students, the Industrial Mathematical and Statistical Modeling (IMSM) workshop, where participants work on projects originating in government labs or industry. Collectively, the undergraduate and graduate student workshops engage about 130 students per year drawn from across the US.

The grant being reported here (DMS 1127914) was the third in a series of grants from NSF starting in 2002. It covered the academic years 2012/13 through 2016/17. During this period, SAMSI organized year-long research programs on the following topics:

Statistical and Computational Methodology for Massive Datasets (2012-13),

Data Driven Decision in Healthcare (2012-13),

Low-Dimensional Structure in High-Dimensional Systems (2013-14),

Computational Methods in Social Sciences (2013-14),

Beyond Bioinformatics: Statistical and Mathematical Challenges (2014-15),

Mathematical and Statistical Ecology (2014-15),

Challenges in Computational Neuroscience (2015-16),

Statistics and Applied Mathematics in Forensic Science (2015-16),

Statistical, Mathematical and Computational Methods for Astronomy (2016-17),

Optimization (2016-17).

Summer programs and free-standing workshops were organized on the following topics:

Computational Advertising (Summer 2012),

Modern Statistical and Computational Methods for Analysis of Kepler Data (Summer 2013),

Neuroimaging Data Analysis (Summer 2013),

Dynamics of Seismicity, Earthquake Clustering and Patterns in Fault Networks (October 2013),

The International Surface Temperature Initiative (Summer 2014),

Uncertainties in Computational Hemodynamics (Summer 2015),

Bayesian Nonparametrics: Synergies between Statistics, Probability and Mathematics (Summer 2015),

Methodology for Precision Medicine: Integrating Statistical and Mathematical Approaches (April 2016),

Games and Decisions in Reliability and Risk (May 2016),

Distributed and Parallel Data Analysis (September 2016),

Data-Driven Modeling of Collective Behavior and Emergent Phenomena in Biology (June 2017),

STATMOS/SAMSI Workshop on Climate (July 2017).

Intellectual Merit

SAMSI programs have resulted in research publications in all the major journals for statistics, applied mathematics and operations research, as well as journals in disciplines as varied as social sciences, genetics, ecology and geosciences. Contributions have ranged from theoretical advances such as the development of new scalable algorithms for optimization, to very applied contributions such as the analysis of massive datasets in astronomy and climate science.  SAMSI programs have also resulted in new software and in research sessions at numerous major conferences. Its interactions with two major professional societies (ASA and SIAM) have contributed to new activity or interest groups in those societies.

Broader Impacts

SAMSI activities enrich careers ranging from undergraduate students to senior researchers from around the nation. SAMSI also provides training for careers through professional development workshops. Postdoctoral fellows and graduate students are introduced to collaborative research in the working groups and through summer modeling workshops. In the SAMSI graduate courses, students learn about state-of-the-art and interdisciplinary research topics that are not typically covered within traditional campus courses. SAMSI’s undergraduate workshops give students insight into modern research themes and guidance on pursuing a research career. SAMSI reaches out to diverse communities including institutions serving under-represented minorities. It has public outreach through public lectures, press releases and blogs.
